ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed both a linguistic and cultural understanding of the Greek language and how this ties in with its culture. I learned specifically about the different tenses used in everyday speech which allowed me to develop my speaking skills and improved my general conversational ability.
Further developed my written and oral abilities in the Modern Greek language, as well as gained knowledge and insights to the Greek culture.
Strongly developed my understanding and communication abilities in grammar, vocabulary, speaking, and cultural awareness.

I learned a lot of language skills this semester, including general vocabulary, subjunctive, future tense, and past tense. My proficiency improved on all fronts: reading, writing, listening, and speaking. I also had the opportunity to learn some cultural aspects of modern-day Greece.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The asynchronous day in this course is definitely a strength in that we were able to engage with Greek students from Greece and challenge our conversational skills. The pace at which the class progressed with content was very beneficial in that no one was left behind and that we could cover a lot of material.
This is a very strong course overall.

I think that the biggest strength of this course is its near-immersive environment. I thought that one of the most unique and helpful aspects of the course this semester was its pilot asynchronous program, in which class on Fridays was asynchronous, and every other Friday we would have a tele-collaboration with students in Thessaloniki. This gave me the opportunity to practice my spoken Greek with native speakers, and to present on some of the material we were learning during the course this semester. I think that one of the weaknesses of this course is that not all of the students took the work seriously, and as a result we had to slow down the pace of the course because their level of proficiency had fallen behind.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class to other students who are looking for a fun and stimulating language to study. Also to those who are interested in the nuances of language and who like connecting etymology of English/other Latin languages to Greek and vice versa.

Absolutely.  Maria (course instructor) is so passionate about the Greek language and culture, but is also incredibly invested in the success and well being of her students.  Truly an outstanding learning opportunity in more ways than one could imagine.
ABSOLUTELY. Its an incredible learning experience.

I would recommend this course (both L1 and L2) to another student if they are interested in learning a new language or if they are a heritage speaker but their Greek has gotten a lot worse since they were younger. I think this course is an amazing opportunity to learn and practice the modern Greek language, an opportunity which cannot be found at all colleges. I would not recommend this course to another student if they are only taking the course because they think it will be a gut. You will fall behind if you do not take the workload seriously, and it is unfair to the other students who are serious about improving their Greek, and it is especially unfair to the professor.
